metadata.title: Insight into the Co(II)/NaOH and Cu(II)/NaOH catalytic oxidation of 4-methyl guaiacol: Structures of catalysts and reaction pathways

INSIGHTCOIINAOHCUIINAOHCATALYTICOXIDATION4METHYLGUAIACOLSTRUCTURESCATALYSTSREACTIONPATHWAYS LIU K 1 Introduction 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents 2.2 General procedure for oxidation of 4-methylguaiacol 2.3 Analysis of reaction products 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Different catalytic processes of Co(II)/NaOH from Cu(II)/NaOH system 3.2 Different structures of the Co(II)/NaOH and Cu(II)/NaOH catalysts 3.2.1 Heterogeneous reaction of both Cu(II)/NaOH and Co(II)/NaOH catalysis 3.2.2 Hierarchic structures of Cu(II)/NaOH catalyst 3.2.3 “Layered double-hydroxide” structure—co (II) to Co(IV) 3.3 Similarities and differences among the mechanisms of the Co(II)/NaOH and Cu(II)/NaOH catalysts 3.3.1 Cu(II)/NaOH catalysis: single electron transfer reaction 3.3.2 Co(II)/NaOH catalysis: “two-electron” transfer reaction 4 Conclusions Acknowledgements Appendix A Supplementary data References SHI 2012 3381 Z WENDLANDT 2011 11062 A MOSELAGE 2016 498 M MATCZAK 2016 92 P TANIWAKI 2016 11 W ABE 2016 12 H DEVILLE 2016 545 C LABINGER 2004 27 J PIERA 2008 3506 J WANG 2004 633 F WANG 2003 1172 F BARTON 2005 62 B YUAN 2016 284 H JIANG 2013 121 Q JIANG 2013 Q JIANG 2014 2807 J JIANG 2014 1406 J HU 2012 2894 J KSHIRSAGAR 2008 V BECKER 1965 982 H OMURA 1984 3046 K OMURA 1991 921 K GAMEZ 2007 295 P TSURUYA 1976 40 S TSURUYA 1983 47 S TSURUYA 1984 511 S ORLANDO 1968 6 C SHIMIZU 1993 251 M BOLDRON 2005 3585 C MA 2016 45 Q LU 2004 17825 C WEN 2002 1397 X XU 2007 2720 H NI 2009 3868 Y GERKEN 2011 14431 J MCALPIN 2010 6882 J SCHWENZER 2009 5722 B BARDE 2004 299 F SURENDRANATH 2010 16501 Y SYMES 2011 5174 M LEE 2014 9925 J GAMEZ 2001 376 P MOORE 2000 3125 K LIUX2017X24 LIUX2017X24X32 LIUX2017X24XK LIUX2017X24X32XK 2019-03-31T00:00:00Z http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ © 2016 Elsevier B.V. Scheme 1 Catalytic oxygenation of 1 in alkaline EGME. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 General procedure of the oxidation of 4-methyl guaiacol catalytic by CoCl2. Scheme 2 Scheme 3 General procedure for synthesis of the Cu(OH)2 nanomaterial. Scheme 3 Scheme 4 Hydrous “layered double-hydroxide ” structure. Scheme 4 Scheme 5 Some investigations for mechanistic studies. Scheme 5 Scheme 6 Possible mechanism of copper catalytic oxidation of 4-methylguaiacol, single electron transfer pathway (A), two electron transfer pathway (B). Scheme 6 Scheme 7 The possible mechanism for the Co(II)/NaOH system catalytic oxidation. Scheme 7 Fig. 1 Effects of the times by different catalysts in the oxidation of 1. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Electron spin resonance spectrum of Cu-complexes (NaOH/CuCl2 =25:1). (a) Under room temperature, Cu-deposit; (b) T=100K, Cu-deposit; (c) Under room temperature, Cu-filtrate; (d) T=100K, Cu-filtrate. All of them were under N2 and O2 atmosphere, respectively. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 ESR spectrum of Co-clusters (NaOH/CoCl2 =25:1). T=2K, the signals were observed under N2 and O2 atmosphere respectively. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 UV–vis spectra under N2 and O2 atmosphere, respectively, at room temperature, NaOH/CoCl2 =25:1 (mole ratio). A gray solution of Co(II) spectrum (black) bubbled with O2 leads to the yellow solution. The color could not be restored by bubbling with N2. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 The performance of different catalysts. Reaction conditions: EGME, 20.0g; temp, 353.5K; substrate, 50.0mmol; catalyst, 0.1mmol; NaOH, 135.0mmol; O2, 60 ml·min−1; 550rpm; time, 7h. Fig. 5 Table 1 Oxidation of 4-methylguaiacol 1 with molecular oxygen by different catalysts a . Table 1 Entry Catalyst Conv. (%) Selectivity (%) 1 CoCl2·6H2O 99±1 90±1 2 CuCl2·2H2O 87±3 9±2 3 ---- 41±2 4±1 a Reaction conditions: EGME, 20g; temp, 353.5K; substrate, 50mmol; catalyst, 0.1mmol; NaOH, 135mmol; O2, 60mLmin−1; 550rpm; time, 7h. Table 2 Changing the added sequence of the catalysts a . Table 2 Entry Catalyst co-Catalyst (added time(h)) b Conv. (%) Int. (%) Yield. (%) 1 CuCl2·2H2O CoCl2·6H2O(0) 100 Trace 87 2 CuCl2·2H2O CoCl2·6H2O (0.5) 100 4 80 3 CuCl2·2H2O CoCl2·6H2O (1) 100 14 63 4 CuCl2·2H2O CoCl2·6H2O (3) 95 8 60 5 CuCl2·2H2O CoCl2·6H2O (5) 97 Trace 12 a Reaction conditions: EGME, 20g; temp, 353.5K; substrate, 50mmol; catalyst, 0.1mmol; NaOH, 135mmol; O2, 60mLmin−1; 550rpm; time, 7h. b co-Catalyst CoCl2·6H2O was added at the same time, 0.5, 1, 3, and 5h later, respectively. Table 3 Oxidation of 1 to vanillin with filtrate containing Cu2+ a . Table 3 Entry Catalyst Conv. (%) Selectivity(%) 1 CuCl2·2H2O b 87±5 9±2 2 Filtrate 49±5 40±3 a Reaction conditions: temp, 353.5K; substrate, 100mmol; oxygen, 60mlmin−1, 550rpm; time, 7h. b No preliminary, react at the standard condition. China Graphical abstract In excess alkali, 4-methylguaiacol was successfully oxidized to vanillin by Co-salt/NaOH catalytic system with conversion of 100% and selectivity of 90%; however, with conversion of 87% and selectivity of 9% when the catalytic system was replaced by Cu-salt/NaOH. To explore the different catalytic effects, the detailed structural characterizations of the catalysts were carried out by EPR, DLS, and UV–vis technologies. The results suggest that both Co(II)/NaOH and Cu(II)/NaOH systems are heterogeneous and the Co(IV)=O might be an essential factor for the high selectivity in Co(II)-catalysis. Keywords Catalyst structure Mechanism Oxidation 4-methylguaiacol Vanillin 1 Introduction Selective oxidation of substituted p-cresols by transition-metal catalysts is a permanent challenge using molecular oxygen as the terminal oxidant [1–13]. Especially the oxidation of alkyl-substituted phenols to realize direct CH oxyfunctionalization has been attributed to significant efforts [10–19]. Of these, there has been considerable interest in the direct CH carbonylation of 4-methylguaiacol in view of the importance of the generated vanillin, which is used as pharmaceutical intermediate, dye, and an incredibly important flavouring material for industrial production, etc. [14–19]. Guo’s group [14] reported the oxidation of 4-methy guaiacol to vanillin by metalloporphyrins in an alkaline environment. Compared with the different metal ions, T(p-Cl)PPMnCl (tetra(p-chlorophenylporphinato)manganese) was the optimal catalyst, and the catalytic activity of the metal ion Co(II)- and Cu(II)-porphyrin was similar but low. These phenomena were attributed to the electronic arrangement of metal ions. At the end, the mechanism was proposed that the phenolate was oxidized to benzyl radical by the loss of one electron, then the benzyl radical reacted with O2 to form peroxy radical, and finally converted into product. Furthermore, Guo’s group [15] reported that the CC bond of 4-methylguaiacol was coupled into the dimer catalyzed by Co(II)-porphyrin. Herein, the mechanism was considered to be a single electron transfer process (each Co(III) ion was presumed as a one-electron accepter). As a result, phenoxy radicals were coupled to the dimers. Besides, Ji et al. [16,17] reported the oxidation of the substituted p-cresols to aldehydes using Co(II)/NaOH catalytic system with a high activity. Indeed, the first step of the involved mechanism was coincident with that proposed by Guo’s group. Phenolate was converted into the corresponding phenoxy radical by coordination of phenolate and Co(III). However, the following step they proposed was disproportionation of the radicals, generating the intermediate of p-benzoquinone methide rather than being coupled into the dimers or being captured by molecular oxygen. Actually, the disproportionation mechanism has long been recognized in Becker’s paper [20], and was further explained in Omura’s reports [21,22]. It was worth nothing that, in their reports, the substrate was strictly restricted to 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol. On the other hand, the basic copper adducts catalytic oxidative coupling of 2,6-dimethylphenol to polymer has been investigated for more than 50 years [23]. Tsuruya et al. [24–26] have studied this reaction in detail using CuCl2/KOH as catalyst. It was well known that the corresponding polymers or oligomers were produced from the interaction of phenoxy radicals, which came from one-electron oxidation of 2,6-dimethylphenolate. However, the structure and the activated sites of the Cu(II)-catalysts were still ambiguous. In addition, the catalytic oxidation of 2,6-disubstituted 4-cresol to aldehyde by Cu(II)-catalysts has been reported abundantly [27–29]. Shimizu’s group [28] reported an approach of oxidizing the 2,4,6-trimethylphenol to the corresponding aldehyde using Cu(II)-amine as the catalyst. In their research, the formation of p-benzoquinone methide was observed. As mentioned above, the pathways and activities of Co(II)/NaOH and Cu(II)/NaOH catalytic oxidation of p-cresols appeared to be similar. However, our experimental results revealed that 4-methyl guaiacol was successfully oxidized to vanillin by Co-salt/NaOH catalytic system with conversion of 99% and selectivity of 90%; while with conversion of 87% and selectivity of 9% by Cu-salt/NaOH catalytic system, and the main side-products were oligomers (See the following section). It implied that the Co(II)-catalyzed oxidation could not be regarded as a radical reaction simply, considering the consequence of the Cu(II)-catalysis. A reasonable elucidation for the selectivity of CH carbonylation or CC coupling was still absent. These findings have motivated a great interest in the crucial role and determinant of the metal catalysts. Preliminary studies have been carried out on Co-salt/NaOH catalysis in our group [30]. The role of NaOH have been investigated in detail as well as the role of intermediate 4 generated through 1,6-addition of the p-benzoquinone methide with ethylene glycol monomethyl ether (EGME). The kinetic experiments have been performed based on the intermediate of p-benzoquinone methide, which agreed well with the role of NaOH. We elaborated the oxidation of phenolate anion to phenoxyl radical by metal-adducts. In this context, as a continuation of the research, we attempt to further study the oxidation of 4-methylguaiacol by CuCl2(CoCl2)/NaOH/O2 systems (Scheme 1 ). Firstly, the performance of two catalysts in various conditions was investigated to elucidate the catalytic particularity in this reaction. Then, we reported the structures and characteristics of the catalysts in NaOH suspension, which determined the ultimate reaction pathway and product selectivity. Finally, the complementary mechanisms of Co(II)/NaOH and Cu(II)/NaOH catalysis were demonstrated, respectively. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents 4-Methylguaiacol, p-cresol, vanillin, NaOH, and EGME are of analytical grade and purchased from Sahn Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. The O2 and N2 (quality 99.999%) were supplied in the reaction. All of these regents were used without further purification. 2.2 General procedure for oxidation of 4-methylguaiacol A typical procedure for the oxidation of 1 is as follows: EGME (20.0g), 4-methylguaiacol (6.91g, 50mmol), CoCl2·6H2O (0.024g, 0.2%mmol), NaOH (5.40g, 135mmol) were added into a 100mL four-neck bottom flask in sequence. The flask was equipped with magnetic stirring. After the solid were dissolved mostly, oxygen was charged into the flask continuously. The bath temperature was kept at 353K for 7h. Then the flask was cooled to room temperature. The mixture was analyzed by HPLC. 2.3 Analysis of reaction products 4-Methylguaiacol 1, vanillin 2, dimer 3, and ether intermediate 4, were determined by external standard method by HPLC and HPLC–MS. The eluent was comprised of 40% phosphoric acid buffer and 60% CH3OH. The flow rate of 1 ml/min was used with a C18 reversal pillar (size: 150×4.6mm) equipped with a UV detector (279nm). 3 Results and discussion Initially, the model oxidation of 4-methyl guaiacol 1 to vanillin 2 (Scheme 1) was proceeded under a moderate condition to compare the catalytic performance of the two different catalytic systems. Metal-free experiment was investigated as the controlled experiment. The results (Table 1 ) revealed that 4-methylguaiacol could be converted to vanillin 2 (entry 1) with high conversion (99%) and unusual selectivity (90%) using CoCl2 as catalyst. However, in spite of maintaining high conversion (87%), a dramatic decrease of the selectivity (9%) was carried out using the alternate catalyst CuCl2 (entry 2), giving rise to oligomer 3, resulting from CC coupling. Controlled experiment in the absence of transition metal-salt (entry 3) indicated that, for this reaction, the effects of catalysts were remarkable. When there were no transition metal ions, the reaction path was changed, and was triggered by thermocatalysis. As molecular oxygen was partially activated through thermo-activation process from triplet to singlet. Then the phenolate was abstracted one electron to phenoxy radical by molecular oxygen directly. Thus, despite the absent of metal ions, a series of chaotic radical reactions still took place, but almost no target product was generated (Fig. 1 ). It indicated that the catalyst played a critical role in the reaction, allowing the reaction to proceed in the desired direction. In addition, in order to exclude the influence of anions, different anionic metal salts were performed. The results showed that the anions had no effect on the conversion and selectivity. The reason we believed was that the anions were replaced by hydroxide ions in excess alkali. Besides, the effect of the rotational speed was researched (See supporting information table S1). At the same rotational speed, the catalytic activity of cobalt was always better than that of copper. 3.1 Different catalytic processes of Co(II)/NaOH from Cu(II)/NaOH system With the results above in mind, we subsequently performed the studies using the mixed catalysts of CoCl2 and CuCl2 to help us understand the interaction between them. The catalytic performances of the mixed catalysts are presented in Table 2 . We initially added equal amount of the two catalysts at the beginning of the reaction. Surprisingly, the product 2 was still generated selectively, which showed the CoCl2 was dominant in competition with the CuCl2. Moreover, the performance was further studied with CuCl2 and CoCl2 being mixed at the appropriate time. Changing the added sequence and time of the catalysts (Entry 2–5), while CoCl2 as the co-catalyst was added to CuCl2 catalytic system after 0.5, 1, 3, and 5h, respectively, the total yield of vanillin 2 and intermediate 4 gradually reduced from 84, 76, 68, to 12%, which indicated that once CoCl2 was added into the reaction which had been catalyzed by CuCl2, the CC coupling was inhibited versus CH oxidation. A more intuitive kinetic investigation of Entry 2 is presented in Fig. 1. The CoCl2, CuCl2 and metal-free systems were given as the controlled experiments. It clearly indicated that the CH carbonylation catalyzed by CoCl2 was dominant in the reaction which had been catalyzed by CuCl2 for 0.5h, accompanied by the appearance and consumption of the intermediate 4, giving rise to vanillin 2. The kinetic properties of the metallic catalysis were almost the same as those of the Co(II)-catalysis alone, suggesting no synergetic contribution in the Cu(II)/Co(II) catalysts. In other words, the catalytic process of Co(II)/NaOH system is different from that of the Cu(II)/NaOH system. More importantly, the catalytic performance of CoCl2 is not influenced by CuCl2. Actually, almost all of the metals do have no effect on the catalytic process of Co(II)/NaOH system (See supporting information table S2). According to the previous studies, as far as we know, a hypothetical reaction mechanism [30] has been proposed to illustrate the general procedure of the oxidation of 4-methylguaiacol catalyzed by CoCl2 (Scheme 2 ). It was believed that the phenolate was oxidized to phenoxy radical by transferring a single electron to Co(III) Actually, under excess alkaline condition, the catalytic oxidation of phenols by CuCl2 has long been proposed as a radical reaction [26]. And it was confirmed by our experimental results that the Cu(II)-catalysis mainly formed oligomers. However, as described above, the catalytic activity of the Co(II)/NaOH system for the oxidation of 4-methyl guaiacol is completely irrelevant with that of the Cu(II)/NaOH system. These results further reveal that there is a specific mechanism for the formation of p-benzoquinone methide in the Co(II)-catalytic oxidation. 3.2 Different structures of the Co(II)/NaOH and Cu(II)/NaOH catalysts 3.2.1 Heterogeneous reaction of both Cu(II)/NaOH and Co(II)/NaOH catalysis DLS (Dynamic Light Scattering) measurement indicated both Cu(II)/NaOH and Co(II)/NaOH catalysis are heterogeneous reaction. To observe the reaction process of the liquid-phase oxidation of 1, both Cu(II) and Co(II) catalytic reaction mixtures were monitored. DLS measurement results represented the qualitative behavior of the diameters about the samples (Fig. S1 in the Supporting Information). It appeared that after the completion of the reaction, the Z-average of Cu(II)-catalyzed reaction liquid was 9158nm (Fig. S1A), which was consistent with other reports that the catalytic oxidation of the phenols by Cu(II)/NaOH was a heterogeneous reaction [26]. Subsequently, when the larger particles of the Cu(II)-catalyzed reaction liquid were filtered out, the average diameter of the particles in filtrate was decreased to 60nm (Fig. S1 B). These results suggest that the mixture of the Cu(II)-system is indeed consisted of particles with hierarchic sizes. However, the Z-average of Co(II)/NaOH catalyzed reaction mixture was only 112nm (Fig. S1C), which was remarkably smaller than that of the Cu(II)/NaOH system. It clearly manifests that the Co(II)/NaOH catalysis belongs to a heterogeneous reaction. This observation is consistent with other reports [35]. Unfortunately, the DLS technique only gives the average diameter of the particles, and the structural information and activated site are still unknown. Thus other methods were used to explore these details. 3.2.2 Hierarchic structures of Cu(II)/NaOH catalyst The structure of Cu(II)/NaOH catalyst is diverse. Tsuruya and his co-workers have studied the heterogeneous CuCl2/KOH system in CH3OH [24–26]. It inspired us to use the EPR (Electron Paramagnetic Resonance) spectrum to investigate the feature of the catalysts. Firstly, the Cu(II)/NaOH system (NaOH/CuCl2 =25:1, mole ratio, nCu =10−4 mol) was prepared under N2 atmosphere, dissolved in EGME (10g) adequately, then centrifuged the sample, giving rise to deposit and filtrate. The deposit and filtrate were measured under N2 atmosphere, respectively. Under room temperature (Fig. 2 a, c, black line), even T=100K (Fig. 2b, d, black line), the Cu-deposit had no signal while the filtrate had no evident signal. Such results could be explained that Cu(II) interacted with OH− to generate inorganic polymers of Cu(OH)2 in excess alkali. These polymers as precipitation linked by OH− exhibited strong single electron interaction, leading to the disappearance of the Cu(II) signal. Moreover, a large amount of copper precipitated down, resulting in a very low concentration of free Cu (II) ions. Thus no evident Cu(II) signal was observed in Cu-filtrate. Here, the effect of the temperature was neglecTable Secondly, a similar sample was prepared under air and pure O2 was bubbled for 5h. After that, a marked reduction in precipitation was observed. The fresh deposit and filtrate emerged Cu(II) signals under room temperature (Fig. 2a, c, red line), and the prominent signals could be seen under 100K (Fig. 2b, d red line). Obviously, the valence state of copper ions has not changed based on the EPR signal. The new weak peak at g=2.048 in filtrate was a radical signal owing to the coordination of Cu(II) with O2 leading to transference of the single-electron property from Cu(II) to the oxygen, namely, a small amount of (OH)xCuOO• was produced. In view of the difference of the two experimental results, we infer that the role of molecular oxygen, here, mainly weakens the strong single electron interaction of the analogous inorganic polymers of Cu(OH)2, which is consistent with previous reports [24–26]. Part of the inorganic polymers dissociated into the free copper complexes made the appearance of the prominent signal of Cu(II) under O2 atmosphere. In the previous articles, as is well known, the synthesis of the Cu(OH)2 nanomaterial goes through three steps [31–34]. As shown in Scheme 3 , at first, Cu(II) and OH− ions are coordinated to form a series of plane quadrilateral structure. Then, these monomers combine to a chain through the further coordination of Cu(II) and OH−. Finally, these chains interact with each other through hydrogen bond. In our reaction system, the possible formation process of Cu(II) complexes is similar to that of the Cu(OH)2 nanomaterial. Meanwhile, the DLS and EPR experimental results agreed well with the assumption. As the reaction going, it is reasonable to assume that there are concurrent four kinds of Cu(II): mononuclear-like planar Cu-OH complexes (with EPR signal), clusters of diameter about 60nm, larger particle aggregates of diameter near 10μm, and a little amount of (OH)xCuOO•. 3.2.3 “Layered double-hydroxide” structure—co (II) to Co(IV) To get insights into the difference of the Co(II)/NaOH and Cu(II)/NaOH systems, the structural studies of Cu(II)/NaOH catalyst were carried out as mentioned above. Here, the Co(II)/NaOH system was investigated. The DLS measurement results revealed that in the course of the reaction, the synthetic Co(II) particles at excess alkali were aggregated to the clusters having an average size of about 112nm. It made us believe that the Co-cluster was the crucial structure for the distribution of active sites, which should be responsible for the distinction with the general homogeneous Co-catalyst. As we know, the mononuclear Co(OH)2 structure features the layers of octahedral Co(II) coordinated by basal −OH ligands [31]. The oxidation-state change of Co-clusters was investigated through EPR spectroscopic analysis (Fig. 3 ). Firstly, an analogic Co(II)/NaOH system (NaOH/CoCl2 =25:1, mole ratio, nCo =10−4 mol) was prepared under N2 atmosphere, dissolved in EGME (10g) entirely, and the whole process was completely cut off from the oxygen. It meant that regardless of the structure of Co-complex, the valence state is still Co(II). This EPR spectrum exhibited weak signals with g-values of 4.10 and 1.99 (black line), respectively. Then, another sample with pure oxygen bubbled was examined by the same method, and the spectrum mainly exhibited blank signal (red line). The signal/noise ratio was small. A broad peak at the strong field was believed to be the signal of the dissolved oxygen. It has been reported that the Co(III) sites with strong-field ligands are indeed low-spin, which means the Co(III) configuration is EPR-silent [36]. Our spectra data are in a good agreement with the reported conclusion that the Co(II) signal disappears under the oxygen atmosphere resulted from the oxidation-state change (Co(II) to Co(III)). A UV–vis (Ultraviolet-visible) measurement was performed to directly probe the reactivity of Co(II) with O2 (Fig. 4 ). The preparation process of the sample was the same as that of using in EPR. Removing O2, the UV–vis spectra has three absorption peaks, λmax =225, 280, and 600nm, respectively. The peak with λmax =600nm could be unambiguously assigned as the d–d transition of the Co-center. Then O2 was introduced, as time went on, the peak with λmax =600nm gradually disappeared, while a new broad weak peak with λmax =400nm emerged. Removing O2 again by bubbling with N2, the spectra did not restore. With the EPR analysis in mind, these results suggested that in the present of molecular oxygen, the Co(II) was readily oxidized to Co(III), leading to the blueshift of the peak. It could be explained that the d–d transition energy of Co increases from 3d7 to 3d6. And the oxidation process was irreversible. Thus, we could speculate that there was no coordination between the Co(II) and O2 to form the peroxo or superoxo adducts but transferred to Co(III) totally leading to the formation of clusters. With the above-mentioned findings about the structure of Co catalyst, combined with other reports [37], under excess alkaline condition, an octahedral coordination of Co(II) with OH− occurred. This complex could be oxidized to Co(III) by O2, then existed as clusters. The structure of Co-clusters coincides with a hydrous “layered double-hydroxide” structure (Scheme 4 ). As reported, even though the valence state of cobalt was changed, the layer structure remained consistent [39]. In addition, a similar process has been published about the Co(OH) 2 being oxidized to CoOOH under oxygen flow in KOH media [38]. In electrochemistry, the EPR and XAS have been used to establish that the Co(III)-OH can continue to transfer to surface Co(IV)=O site as the critical intermediate of Co-Pi [36,39,40]. At the same time, the cobalt-based oxygen evolution reaction, a similar conversion is also detected in alkaline media [35]. The synthetic Co(O)OH is also thought to contain an amount of Co(IV) [38]. These reports inspires us to assume that in our reaction, the Co-cluster is a layered double-hydroxide material, the internal structure consists of layered Co(O)OH, which can be transferred to Co(IV) by stepwise proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET). As the excess NaOH could accept the proton, and the O2 flow plays a role of oxidant agent. Although the related reports were scarce, the metalloporphyrin experiments (see the following section) prompted us to get this opinion. 3.3 Similarities and differences among the mechanisms of the Co(II)/NaOH and Cu(II)/NaOH catalysts With these structural data in hand, several additional experiments were undertaken to study the mechanisms (Scheme 5 ). Differing from the previous reports, the isotope labeling experiment with 18O2 indicated that the oxygen atom in aldehyde group of product vanillin did not come from the molecular oxygen but the hydroxyl ions (Scheme 6 a, determined by HRMS). In the absence of O2, the conversion about 60% of 1 was realized using the Co(III) as catalyst, but the products were tars (Scheme 6b). It indicated that the stoichiometric Co(acac)3 catalyst could successfully initiate the reaction by changing the valence state of Co(III) to carry the single electron transferred from the phenolate directly, but was invalid at the following step. In fact, it is the most convincing evidence that the primary role of the Co-complexes is not just an initiator. However, under the identical anaerobic conditions, the substitution of Co(acac)3 by stoichiometric CuCl2 promoted the conversion to generate the oligomers, which meant that the activity of Cu(II) was not affected by the lack of O2 (Scheme 6c). Moreover, both Co and Cu catalytic systems, the introduction of the stoichiometric radical initiator 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl (TEMPO) improved the reactivity and selectivity of CC coupling to dimer 3, completely quenched the pathway of CH oxyfunctionalization (Scheme 6d, e). That is quite different from the reported results, as TEMPO is regarded as a radical scavenger for Co(II)-catalytic oxidation. On the other hand, the stoichiometric radical scavenger p-benzoquinone inhibited the reaction of both Co and Cu systems efficiently, clearly manifesting that the first step of both systems was a radical reaction process (Scheme 6f, g). 3.3.1 Cu(II)/NaOH catalysis: single electron transfer reaction Based on the expansive investigations, the critical issue is what the role the structure plays. We attempted to increase the concentration of the dissolved Cu(II) as the following step: 1.5mol% CuCl2 versus raw material was added to reaction flask with the general system except for 4-methylguaiacol, and stirred 24h. After that, the larger particle aggregates were removed by filtration, and the filtrate was used as catalyst system. Then substance was added. As shown in Table 3 , compared with normal catalytic criterion, although the conversion of 1 decreased apparently from 87% to 49%, the selectivity of vanillin 2 increased significantly from 9% to 40%. The results could be explained that removing larger particle aggregates led to the lack of catalytic activated site, meanwhile, indirectly lowered the conversion. Furthermore, there are three kinds of possibilities resulting in the elevated selectivity: (i) mononuclear-like planar Cu-OH complexes; (ii) relatively smaller clusters; (iii) (OH)xCuOO•. All of those still dissolved in liquid. Therein, it is well known that the homogeneous mononuclear-like planar Cu-OH complexes promote to the dimers [24–26]. In addition, the benzoquinone was observed as catalyzed by (OH)xCuOO• [41]. Besides, it has been found that the copper proteins contain a similar copper site that the dinuclear copper species are bridged by hydroxide ions which could be substituted by the phenolate. Most importantly, the two-electron transfer pathway to the quinone methide was in good agreement with our experimental data [42]. Hence, it is reasonable to speculate that the clusters of diameter about 60nm is the inherent catalyst resulting in the oxidation of 4-methylguaiacol to vanillin by two-electron transfer. All of the above-mentioned information about the process of copper catalytic oxidation of 4-methylguaiacol were summarized in the following possible mechanism shown in Scheme 6. Two main pathways were given in Cu(II)-catalyzed reaction. Route A: one-electron transfer pathway. The single electron transfers from the phenolate to the mononuclear-like planar Cu-OH complex or larger aggregate, then the generated phenol radicals were coupled to the dimers or other oligomers. The experimental results indicate that the mechanism of the single electron transfer is the dominant pathway. Route B: two-electron transfer pathway. The phenolates are coordinated with the dinuclear copper species bridged by hydroxide ions, then two electrons transfer from the phenolates to Cu(II) ions, while H+ ions are abstracted by OH− ions dissolved in liquid, giving rise to the quinone methides. Route B is restricted by the amount of the clusters at appropriate size. If the clusters were enough, the performance of catalytic by Cu(II) to synthesize vanillin would be favourable. Besides, the (OH)xCuOO• and particle aggregates should be responsible for other byproducts. 3.3.2 Co(II)/NaOH catalysis: “two-electron” transfer reaction As mentioned above (Scheme 2), the question about Co(II)-catalysis focused on the generation of the p-benzoquinone methide. To further prove the reasonability of Co(IV), the following metalloporphyrin/O2 systems were carried out. As shown in Fig. 5 , the performance of the metalloporphyrin catalysts was observed. It was interesting to note that, three kinds of metalloporphyrin exhibited the catalytic reactivity in varying degrees. However, the activity of metalloporphyrin which comes from the high-valent metal-oxo species using O2 as the terminal oxidant [14,43] has been proposed extensively, such as PFe(III) (Fe-porphyrin) complexes, extracting one O atom from molecular oxygen to generate PFe(IV)=O. Then the intermediate PFe(IV)=O abstracts H• from hydrocarbon to form PFe(III)-OH. Combine with previous evidences, although the method of the formation of the high-valent species is completely different, it is instructive to hypothesized that the CoCl2/NaOH system includes a high-valent Co(IV)=O intermediate which originates from the Co(III) further oxidized by O2. Because of the existence of the high-valent metal-oxo species, it is favourable to generate the vanillin for the metalloporphyrin and CoCl2/NaOH system. Meanwhile, it is consistent with the assumption about the structure of Co-cluster as noted previously. Hence, we proposed a convincing explanation for the CoCl2 catalytic oxidation of p-cresols to the p-benzoquinone methide (Scheme 7 ). Firstly, the Co(II)-salt dissolved in EGME with extensive NaOH preferentially coordinated with OH− leading to the formation of the heterogeneous Co(O)OH as fast oxidation by O2. Then partial of surface Co(O)OH proceed with oxidation to Co(IV) via stepwise proton-coupled electron transfer process. Meanwhile, the phenolate prior to react with Co(III) to obtain the peroxy radical through single electron transfer which made Co(III) reduced to Co(II). Then the activated benzylic CH bond was further oxidized by stepwise giving up one hydrogen proton and one electron to Co(IV)=O (see the following equation). Co(IV)=O+H· Co(III)-OH The highly activated p-benzoquinone methide obtained ultimately. The proposed mechanism has the following characteristics: (i)“layered double-hydroxide” structure; (ii) Co(IV)=O intermediate; (iii) stepwise proton-coupled electron transfer process. 4 Conclusions The overall goal in this study was to get a new perspective on the catalytic processes of 4-methyl guaiacol, as the experimental results showed that the catalytic behavior of Co(II)-catalyst was more complicated than that of Cu(II)-catalyst. These encouraged us to get insight into the differences catalyzed by Cu(II)/Co(II)-NaOH. It highlighted the structures and patterns of catalysts in detail. Then a plausible explanation was further proposed for the different mechanisms of catalytic oxidation of substituted p-cresols by Co(II) and Cu(II), respectively. The selectivity of the product in CH oxidation versus CC coupling catalyzed by metal-complexes of Co(II) and Cu(II) is related to the different activated sites. The catalytic activity of the Co(II)/NaOH system depends essentially on the structure of Co(IV)=O. That is the critical fact in this process leading to the different catalytic performances. Stepwise proton-coupled electron transfer process ensured the oxidation of the 4-methyl guaiacol to vanillin successfully when catalytic amount of bimetallic catalyst was used. Most of the generated free radicals, whether catalyzed by CoCl2 or CuCl2, were consumed by Co(IV)=O. However, the certification of Co(IV) remains a challenging project which still needs further investigation. Nevertheless, we anticipate that these findings will be helpful in understanding the CH oxidation of substituted cresols deeply, and give some inspirations in choosing the transition metallic catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In excess alkali, 4-methylguaiacol was successfully oxidized to vanillin by Co-salt/NaOH catalytic system with conversion of 100% and selectivity of 90%; however, with conversion of 87% and selectivity of 9% when the catalytic system was replaced by Cu-salt/NaOH. To explore the different catalytic effects, the detailed structural characterizations of the catalysts were carried out by EPR, DLS, and UV–vis technologies. The results suggest that both Co(II)/NaOH and Cu(II)/NaOH systems are heterogeneous and the Co(IV)=O might be an essential factor for the high selectivity in Co(II)-catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into the Co(II)/NaOH and Cu(II)/NaOH catalytic oxidation of 4-methyl guaiacol: Structures of catalysts and reaction pathways
